title: Simplify install.sh: hardcode repo, remove dead schedule code, drop all sed
body:
## Context

Running `install.sh` on macOS fails with:
```
sed: 1: ".github/workflows/versi ...": invalid command code .
```

BSD sed requires `sed -i ''` vs GNU sed's `sed -i`. But deeper analysis shows the sed calls are either dead code (schedule substitution against templates that don't have the placeholder) or unnecessary complexity (SEMVER_REPO param for hypothetical forks).

## Acceptance Criteria

### install.sh changes
- [ ] Remove the `SEMVER_REPO` parameter — script takes only `<version>`
- [ ] Remove all schedule/cron code (lines 52-70: read/validate, lines 88-91: sed substitute) — dead code, templates have no schedule placeholder
- [ ] Remove all `sed` calls from `install_workflow()` — no substitution needed
- [ ] Update usage comment and header to reflect single-param interface
- [ ] `install_workflow()` just fetches the template, no post-processing

### Template changes
- [ ] `templates/github/workflows/install-git-semver.yml`: change `SEMVER_REPO: USER/git-semver` to `SEMVER_REPO: mangimangi/git-semver`

### README changes
- [ ] Remove `install.schedule` from config docs (line ~165, ~209)
- [ ] Remove "Runs weekly to check for updates" mention (line ~28)
- [ ] Simplify install command examples to `bash -s <version>` (drop repo param)

### Workflow changes
- [ ] Update `.github/workflows/install-git-semver.yml` (the repo's own workflow) to pass only version to install.sh (drop repo param from `bash -s` call)
- [ ] Update `.github/workflows/install-on-release.yml` if it also passes repo param

### Tests
- [ ] Add `tests/test_install.sh` (shell tests) or `tests/test_install.py` (pytest) that verify:
  - install.sh creates `.semver/git-semver`, `.semver/.version`, `.semver/config.json`
  - install.sh installs workflow templates when not present
  - install.sh skips workflow templates when already present
  - Installed workflow templates contain `mangimangi/git-semver` (not placeholder)

title: git-block: generic vendor file protection tool
Implement check-vendor.yml workflow + config schema
Implement git-block install.sh
body:
The consumer-facing installer for git-block. Sets up .block/ directory, config, and workflow in a target repo.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `git-block/install.sh` implemented:
  - Creates `.block/` directory
  - Initializes `.block/config.json` with empty `vendors` object if missing (preserves existing config on update)
  - Installs `check-vendor.yml` to `.github/workflows/` (always overwrites — it's implementation, not config)
  - Registers git-block itself as a vendor:
    - `install_branch`: `chore/install-git-block`
    - `protected`: `.block/**`, `.github/workflows/check-vendor.yml`
    - `allowed`: `.block/config.json`
  - Writes version to `.block/.version`
- [ ] `git-block/VERSION` file created
- [ ] Tests: fresh install creates expected structure, update preserves existing config, self-registration is correct
- [ ] Docs: installation section in `git-block/README.md`

## Context

Follows the same pattern as git-semver's install.sh — download + place files, create config if missing, preserve config on update. The install script is the entry point for consumer repos adopting git-block.

title: Add git-block self-registration to git-semver install.sh
body:
When git-semver installs in a consumer repo, register its protected/allowed files with git-block if .block/config.json is present.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `install.sh` updated: if `.block/config.json` exists, register git-semver vendor config:
  - `install_branch`: `chore/install-git-semver`
  - `protected`: `.semver/**`, git-semver workflow files (`.github/workflows/version-bump.yml`, `.github/workflows/install-git-semver.yml`)
  - `allowed`: `.semver/config.json`, `.semver/.version`
- [ ] Registration uses the inline python pattern from the git-block design doc:
  ```python
  import json
  with open('.block/config.json') as f:
      config = json.load(f)
  config.setdefault('vendors', {})
  config['vendors']['git-semver'] = { ... }
  with open('.block/config.json', 'w') as f:
      json.dump(config, f, indent=2)
      f.write('\n')
  ```
- [ ] No-op when `.block/config.json` doesn't exist (git-block not installed)
- [ ] Tests: registration adds correct config entries, no-op without git-block, preserves existing vendor registrations
- [ ] Docs: mention git-block integration in git-semver README

## Context

This is the vendor self-registration pattern — each tool's install script registers its own files with git-block. The check workflow stays generic and config-driven.

title: Replace check-pearls-impl.yml with git-block in this repo
body:
Migrate this repo (as a consumer) from the bespoke check-pearls-impl.yml to git-block's generic check-vendor.yml.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] git-block installed in this repo (`.block/` directory, `check-vendor.yml` workflow)
- [ ] Pearls vendor registered in `.block/config.json` matching current check-pearls-impl.yml protections:
  - `install_branch`: `chore/install-pearls`
  - `protected`: `.pearls/**`
  - `allowed`: `.pearls/issues.jsonl`, `.pearls/config.json`, `.pearls/.prl-version`, `.pearls/archive/*.jsonl`
- [ ] `.github/workflows/check-pearls-impl.yml` removed
- [ ] Verification: document that check-vendor.yml catches the same violation cases as the removed workflow (protected files flagged, allowed files pass, install branch skipped)

## Depends on

- gsv-2697.1 (check-vendor.yml workflow)
- gsv-2697.2 (git-block install.sh)

## Context

check-pearls-impl.yml is ~200 lines of bespoke bash that hard-codes knowledge of .pearls/, .semver/, hooks, and workflows. git-block replaces this with a ~50 line config-driven workflow. The pearls vendor config registered here will eventually be managed by pearls' own install.sh (tracked as a separate pearls issue), but for initial migration we register it manually.
